Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Causes and consequences of early reproduction in mangroves invading salt marshes

Worldwide, tropical mangroves are expanding their ranges into temperate salt marsh habitat. In some locations, mangrove seedlings reproduce much earlier than usual, only one to two years after establishing. This precocious reproduction may facilitate rapid invasion of mangroves into salt marshes by shortening generation times of the invading plants. Shorter generation time allows the leading edge of the mangrove invasion to move at an even faster pace than with climate change alone. This research will investigate the causes of precocious reproduction in invasive mangroves and the ecological consequences of precocious reproduction on mangroves invading salt marshes. Research methods include field and laboratory experiments and ecological modeling.

The study will contribute to understanding of floral induction, which is well understood in Arabidopsis but is more complex in trees experiencing complex interactions of light quality and quantity, photoperiod, temperature and water stress. This system is ideal to test how rapid life history changes affect the success of an invasive species. The fellowship will broaden participation in biology by preparing a minority researcher for a scientific leadership position in academia, attracting diverse undergraduates to participate in research, and creating an educational exhibit from research findings. The fellow will receive training in physiological methods and ecological modeling, and will mentor undergraduate researchers, preparing her for a research and teaching career in biology. Results from this study will be developed into an exhibit for public display at the Smithsonian Marine Ecosystems Exhibit in Ft. Pierce, Florida.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Worldwide, species are responding to climate change by moving into new geographic areas (a range expansion) or shrinking the area in which they live (a range contraction). Mangroves are woody plants that occur in coastal zones in the tropics. A lack of recent freezes at higher latitudes has allowed mangroves to expand their ranges poleward into temperate salt marshes. However, the success of newly established populations of mangroves is not guaranteed—small, isolated populations can face challenges such as slow growth, low reproductive rates and a lack of genetic diversity. Initial observations indicated that in the newly established northern populations, mangroves have started reproducing at a younger age (Fig.1A). This project sought to understand the causes of the early reproduction in mangroves at their northern range edge, and to examine the consequences of this early reproduction for mangroves expanding into salt marshes.

This project documented reproductive rates of red mangroves from populations at the northern limit of the range in northern Florida and from populations further south in Florida. Mangrove populations at the northern range edge had more individuals reproducing at an early age than southern populations (Fig. 2). Typically, these plants take 5-10 years to reproduce and at their northern limit they are reproducing by the age of two.

An additional aspect of this study was to examine genetic diversity in black mangroves in northern Florida populations. When species expand their ranges, they could lose genetic diversity, jeopardizing future populations that establish. This study found that the more recently established populations in northern Florida do not have significantly less genetic diversity than older, more southern populations. This is most likely due to long-distance movement by mangrove seeds through water.

During the fellowship, the PI for this project mentored female high school and undergraduate students to train them for careers in science. She also gave talks to the public near the research sites in Florida and disseminated research results to staff at the Florida state parks and the National Estuarine Research Reserve where the work was done. The training provided by this project prepared the fellowship recipient for a career as a professor, during which she will teach, conduct research and mentor students in science.
